bibl.title: Letter from Jno [John] H. Smith to Henry Rose Carter, May 10, 1923

div1.p: Smith provides detailed information on the steamer traffic between South America, Asia and Australia.

div1.head: Letter from Jno [John] H. Smith to Henry Rose Carter, May 10, 1923
div1.opener:
ZEAL OF THE CANAL ZONE ESTR OF PANAMA
* * *
THE PANAMA CANAL
CANAL ZONE
EXECUTIVE DEPARTMENT
Balboa Heights, C. Z.
May 10, 1923.
IN REPLY REFER TO FILE
CABLE ADDRESS:
“PANCANAL, PANAMA”
Dr. Henry R. Carter,
2121 California St., N.W.,
Washington, D. C.
Sir:
div1.p:
Referring to your letter of April 18, 1923, to Dr. W. C. Rucker,
Chief Quarantine Officer, The Panama Canal, requesting data relative to
steamer traffic between the west coast of Central and South America to
Asia and Australia:

At the present time there are no lines direct from west Central
and South American ports to Australia excepting those transiting the Canal
en route from North American and European ports. A number of these stop
at Canal ports for taking on or discharging passengers or freight, but as
you are aware we have had no yellow fever on the Isthmus for a number of
years and the chances of introduction from this source would be quite re-
mote. These vessels go direct to either New Zealand or Australian ports
and the voyage takes approximately three to four weeks after clearing from
Canal ports.

The Toyo Kisen Kaisha Line has sailings approximately once every
seven weeks between west Central and South American ports and eastern Asia.
Ports of call include Valparaiso, Iquique, Antofagasta, and Arica, Chile;
Pisco, Mollendo, and Callao, Peru; Balboa, Canal Zone; Manzanillo and
Salina Cruz (optional), Mexico; Los Angeles and San Francisco, U.S.A.;
Honolulu, Manila, Moji, Kobe, Yokohama, Hongkong, and Shanghai. The ves-
sels of this line carry both passengers and freight, and the voyage con-
sumes about five weeks after leaving Manzanillo, Mexico, before touching
at Asiatic ports. First, second and third class passengers are handled,
the latter predominating, and they frequently carry as high as 200 passeng-
ers per trip. Four of the vessels that have been employed on this route
are the “Rakuyo Maru”, “Seiyo Maru”, “Anyo Maru”, and “Ginyo Maru”, and
their respective registered gross tonnages are, 9,419, 6,550, 9,257 and
8,600 tons.

The “Hwah Ping”, a vessel of 4,254 tons registered gross, owned
by the Chinese Government, has made two round trips within the past year
between China and west South and Central American ports. This vessel also
carries both freight and passengers and the itinerary is much the same as
that of the Toyo Kisen Kaisha. Whether this will develop into a regular
service or not is problematical.

As in the Australian traffic, there are a number of lines
transiting the Canal for Asiatic ports, some of which load supplies or
cargo at Canal ports, but none of these call at west Central or South
American ports after transiting the Canal.
div1.closer:
Respectfully, JNO. H. SMITH
Acting Executive Secretary 42
